column3: and design a satellite that will achieve the aims. Don't worry about money - just make something that works!

The UK Space Agency is planning its next satellite mission. They've asked you to help design it!

Your role is to design and launch a satellite that can perform a specific role related to communications
column3: navigation or earth observation. You’ll need to select the size of your satellite along with its instruments and power supply. Once it’s completed
column4: you’ll need to design a rocket capable of launching your satellite into orbit — will you succeed?

column2: Switch between viewing fullscreen or in a standard browser window
Satellites have different purposes. Which type do you want to build?
Select the purpose of your satellite
Make sure to take a note of the budget you have. You will need to make sure you don't overspend.
Choose the size of your satellite
The size of your satellite matters. It needs to be big enough to hold all the instruments you need. Be careful though. The bigger your satellite
column3: the more expensive it is.

column2: Select the orbit for your satellite
There are several different orbits around the Earth that you can choose from. Higher orbits need more powerful rockets to get to them.
Select the instruments for your satellite
To complete your mission you will need the correct instruments. Instruments are separated by size
column3: shown by colour. Make sure the colour of your instrument matches an available slot. You only have a limited number of slots
column4: so choose wisely!

column2: Your satellite needs power. There are different ways to do that. You can use solar panels on the sides of the satellite
column3: deployable solar panels
column4: and an RTG. Batteries can store energy in order to power the satellite when it's not in direct sunlight.

column2: Now you have a satellite you need to build a multi-stage rocket. The top of the rocket will hold your satellite
column3: so needs to be big enough. You can have up to three rocket stages
column4: which need to be big enough to support those above - and provide enough thrust to reach your chosen orbit.

column2: We've detected problems with your mission. These should be fixed before trying to launch or your mission will fail.
Final checks have shown that your mission is within budget
column3: you have a suitable rocket
column4: and you have a satellite that will achieve your goals. Mission Control is waiting for you to give the OK.

column2:
The UK Space Agency is planning its next satellite mission. They've asked you to help design it!

This app challenges students to design and launch a satellite that can perform a specific role related to communication
column3: navigation or earth observation. They’ll need to select the size of their satellite along with its instruments and power supply. Once completed
column4:
they’ll be challenged to design a rocket capable of launching the satellite into orbit.

Older or more capable students may want to use Intermediate and Advanced mode. Intermediate mode challenges students to build their satellite and launcher on a strict budget. Advanced mode provides a much greater range of options and challenges students to select the correct orbit for their satellite based on its purpose.

column2: Satellites in low-Earth orbit pass over a different part of the Earth in each orbit. It is cheaper to send satellites to Low-Earth orbit than other orbits and satellites here can be reached for repairs. Low-Earth orbit satellites can look at small areas in high detail for short periods of time.
Satellites in medium-Earth orbit are higher above the Earth than low-Earth orbits
column3: but lower than geostationary orbits. They cover a different part of Earth in each orbit. They can see a larger area in less detail than low-Earth orbits.

column2: Highly-elliptical orbits are much closer to the Earth at one point in their orbit than another
column3: giving an elongated (elliptical) rather than circular orbit. They are useful for covering areas including polar regions. More than one satellite can be used for continuous coverage of an area.

column2: Satellites in geostationary orbits stay above the same location on Earth near the equator and complete a full orbit in 24 hours. They are much higher above the Earth's surface than other orbits
column3: so can see the entire hemisphere in less detail.

The global positioning system is made up of 24 satellites that orbit at an altitude of <span data-dimension="length" data-units="km" data-value="20000" class="value convertable">20
column3: 000 km above the surface of the Earth. The difference in time for signals received from four satellites is used to calculate the exact location of a GPS receiver on Earth.

column2: Uses signals from four navigation satellites so satnav users can find their location on Earth. Need to be able to see half a hemisphere at a time

column2: These satellites are used to image clouds and measure temperature and rainfall. Both geostationary and low Earth orbits are used depending on the type of weather satellite. Weather satellites are used to help with more accurate weather forecasting. These are used to photograph and image the Earth. Low Earth orbits are mainly used so that more detailed images can be produced.

Monitor weather systems so forecasters can predict future weather. Weather satellites need to be able to take images of clouds and use infrared light to measure the temperatures of the ground and ocean.
